item.title: Iran in Its Most Fragile Situation in 'Decades', Former UK Ambassador to Iran Says
item.description: After continued waves of missile strikes from Israel, Iran finds itself in a precarious position says Nicholas Hopton, Director General of the Middle East Association and former UK Ambassador to Iran. To try and aid its cause, it is likely that Iran is in negotiations with China and Russia for support says Hopton, as the relationship between Iran and Russia has developed 'a lot in recent years'. Hopton spoke to Tom Mackenzie on 'Bloomberg: The Pulse' (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: German Investor Confidence Jumps as Fiscal Boost Outweighs Trade
item.description: Investor confidence in Germany’s economy improved more than anticipated as a forthcoming surge in public spending outweighs fears over looming US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: Stocks Struggle on Cusp of Record as Risks Mount
item.description: JPMorgan trading desk says it’s time to pare back on risk
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova, Phil Serafino

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump departs following a group photo during the G7 Leaders' Summit in Canada on June 16. Photographer: Pool/Getty Images

item.title: Oil Fluctuates as Traders Watch for Israel-Iran War Escalation
item.description: Oil fluctuated as traders parsed comments from President Donald Trump on the conflict between Israel and Iran, with the market on edge about potential crude supply disruptions in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Alex Longley

item.title: Trump Plays Down Iran-Israel Ceasefire, China Oil Demand Forecast Cut | Bloomberg The Pulse 06/17
item.description:
US President Donald Trump left the Group of Seven leaders meeting in Canada early to deal with the Israel-Iran conflict, but played down the chances of a ceasefire. On Tuesday morning, he returned to Washington and criticized French President Emmanuel Macron for saying the move was possibly a sign he was working on a truce. “Wrong!,” Trump said in reference to Macron on Truth Social. “He has no idea why I am now on my way to Washington, but it certainly has nothing to do with a Cease Fire. Much bigger than that. Stay Tuned!” Trump hasn’t clearly spelled out his next steps as he returns to the US capital. Israel and Iran continue to strike on one another.
Today's guests: Jim Reid, Deutsche Bank Head of Global Macro and Thematic Research, Nicholas Hopton, Middle East Association Director General and former UK Ambassador to Iran, Andy Cronin, Avolon CEO. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed Stuck With ‘Torn’ Dual Mandate, Economist Slok Says
item.description: Torsten Slok, chief economist at Apollo Global Management, examines the challenges facing the Federal Reserve in this week’s interest-rate decision. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Futures Fall as Risk Builds Around Israel-Iran War: Markets Wrap
item.description: US equity futures dropped and oil rallied as sentiment turned negative on fears of escalation in Israel’s war with Iran after US President Donald Trump played down the likelihood of a ceasefire.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Julien Ponthus

item.title: Trump: ‘Not Too Much in the Mood’ to Negotiate With Iran
item.description: President Trump reiterated that Iran should have made a deal with the US prior to Israeli airstrikes as he spoke with reporters on Air Force One Tuesday as he returned early from the Group of Seven leaders meeting in Canada to deal with the Israel-Iran conflict. Joumanna Bercetche reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Trump’s Latest Attack on the Fed Zooms In on Surging Debt Costs
item.description: Donald Trump is putting new spin on his months-long call for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates: It’s important for bringing down the cost of government debt.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

item.title: Softbank-Backed Lenskart Said to Near Filing for $1 Billion IPO
item.description: Softbank Group Corp.-backed Lenskart Solutions Pvt, India’s largest eyewear maker, is preparing to file preliminary documents in the coming weeks for an initial public offering that may fetch about $1 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Rajesh Mascarenhas, Baiju Kalesh

media:content.media:description: A Lenskart store in in Kolkata.

item.title: India Grows Nuke Arsenal and Repositions Warheads, Report Says
item.description: India has slightly increased its nuclear arsenal, modernized its delivery systems and appears to be changing the way it prepares warheads by keeping them closer to missile launch systems, a report from a weapons research group said.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta

item.title: Thai Cabinet Approves $1.3 Billion Plan for F1 Race in Bangkok
item.description: Thailand’s cabinet approved a proposal for Bangkok to host a Formula One race for at least five years starting in 2028, earmarking 41.4 billion baht ($1.3 billion) in an effort to boost the nation’s image as a venue for international events and luxury tourism.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

item.title: IEA Says China Oil Demand to Peak Earlier Than Expected
item.description: The International Energy Agency said China’s oil demand will stop growing earlier than expected. The IEA predicts the nation’s demand will top out in 2027, and worldwide oil use two years after that. Bloomberg’s Anthony di Paola reports.

item.title: Gold Swings as Traders Track Conflict Between Israel and Iran
item.description: Gold fluctuated as investors tracked hostilities in the Middle East, following a report that Israel may have set back Tehran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Jason Scott

media:content.media:description: One kilogram gold bars at the ABC Refinery smelter, operated by Pallion, in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Gold paused its record-breaking rally amid optimism over US-Japan trade talks, after bullion earlier reached another all-time high. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: Wall Street Turns Wary as Mideast Risk Caps Stocks Near Record
item.description: Flaring tension in the Mideast is adding to worries over inflation and the timing of US interest-rate cuts, prompting at least one Wall Street firm to turn cautious on the prospect of the stock market’s climb toward another all-time high.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: Mali to Take Control of Key Barrick Gold Mine for Six Months
item.description: A Malian court ruled that Barrick Mining Corp.’s Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex should be placed under provisional administration for six months, handing control of one of the Canadian company’s biggest operations to state-appointed management.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Diakaridia Dembele, Jacob Lorinc

media:content.media:description: Dumper trucks collect rock ore from from the digging floor in a section of the Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Berjaya Land to Explore Rare Earth Mining in Malaysia’s Perlis
item.description: Berjaya Land Bhd. is set to explore and develop the mining of rare earth elements and other minerals in Malaysia’s northern Perlis state.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: Japanese Bonds Fall After BOJ Plans Slower Cuts to Bond Buying
item.description: Japan’s government bonds fell on Tuesday, nudging yields higher, even after the central bank outlined plans to slow the tapering of its debt purchases in the wake of recent market turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass

item.title: ECB Amends Bank Capital Reviews to Reflect Extreme Weather Risks
item.description: The European Central Bank is embedding climate risk into regular reviews of how well banks can absorb losses, marking a new chapter in its supervisory approach.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: Homes beside a riverbed destroyed after flash floods in Chiva, Spain in 2024.

item.title: Taiwan Dollar, Baht Most at Risk From Oil Price, Barclays Says
item.description: A surging oil price is likely to trigger a depreciation in Asian currencies, notably the Thai baht, Taiwan dollar and Korean won, according to Barclays Plc.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Bosley

media:content.media:description: A worker at a gas station in Bangkok. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

item.title: What Happens to Equities If the Strait of Hormuz Closes?
item.description: Deutsche Bank Global Macro and Thematic Research Head Jim Reid discusses the impact of tensions between Israel and Iran on equity markets and what a potential closure of the Strait of Hormuz could mean for oil prices. "If the Strait of Hormuz got closed then our guys think oil would go to 120," Reid tells Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ECB Has Found ‘Equilibrium’ on Rates, Prices, Growth, Stournaras Says
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Yannis Stournaras says it seems the euro area has reached an equilibrium when it comes to inflation, banking-sector developments and economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

item.title: London’s Credit Market Is Drying Up as UK Plc Raises Debt Abroad
item.description: The City of London has had to contend with a lot in recent years, from Brexit to a lack of stock listings. Its latest setback is the rapid decline of the sterling corporate bond market.
item.dc:creator: Tasos Vossos

item.title: Modi Misses Chance to Push for US Trade Deal as Trump Leaves G-7
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi had no opportunity to push for a US trade deal with Donald Trump after the American president left the Group of Seven leaders’ summit early, a potential setback for New Delhi as recent tariff negotiations hit hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, center, arrives at Calgary Airport on June 16. Photographer: Dave Chidley/Getty Images

item.title: SoftBank Sells T-Mobile Stake for $4.8 Billion to Bet on AI
item.description: SoftBank Group Corp. raised around $4.8 billion through a sale of T-Mobile US Inc. shares, a move that helps fund the Japanese company’s grandiose plans for artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: A T-Mobile store in New York, US, on Monday, Oct. 21, 2024. T-Mobile US Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on October 23.

item.title: Iron Ore Extends Drop as Demand Concerns Rise, Citi Cuts Targets
item.description: Iron ore headed for the lowest close since September on a seasonal slowdown in demand and signs Chinese mills are curbing steel output.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell, Winnie Zhu

item.title: DayOne Seeks $1 Billion Private Credit for Data Center Expansion
item.description: DayOne Data Centers Singapore Pte. is seeking a private credit loan of at least $1 billion to fund its expansion plans, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Megawati Wijaya, Kari Soo Lindberg

media:content.media:description: A computer server. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Saudi SNB Taps Debt Market as Lenders Binge on Bonds
item.description: Saudi National Bank is teeing up a dollar-denominated debt sale, continuing a borrowing spree by the kingdom’s lenders that are helping finance a $2 trillion economic overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Christine Burke, Colin Keatinge

media:content.media:description: The Saudi National Bank headquarters in Riyadh.

item.title: Philippine Peso Heads for Longest Losing Run in Over a Year
item.description: The Philippine peso is on track for its longest stretch of losses in more than a year, weighed down by a surge in global oil prices.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani

item.title: Citi Calls Time on Gold’s Rally on Slumping Demand, Fed Cuts
item.description: Gold is expected to sink back below $3,000 an ounce in the coming quarters as a record-setting run peters out, according to Citigroup Inc., calling time on one of the standout rallies in commodities.
item.dc:creator: Jake Lloyd-Smith

media:content.media:description: One kilogram gold bars at The Vaults Group gold dealers arranged in Barcelona, Spain, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Gold was steady after dropping Tuesday as President Donald Trump eased the impact of some auto tariffs and pointed to progress in trade negotiations with several countries. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
